Opening was fine, but with how much gen 1 nostalgia there is, the part where they show more modern scenes feel more like an afterthought. If they were going to give the other Pokemon/companions just 5 seconds as a "they are here too!" I'd have rather have a gen 1 only opening. Hopefully as more episodes are released, the opening will evolve into one celebrating the Pokemon anime as a whole instead of this weird mix.
The episode itself was fine, just Ash interacting with the world around him. I appreciated seeing him using reserves, and was surprised they were so varied instead of being Kanto/Journeys mons, I was expecting him to run just with Pikachu for the first few episodes.
Considering this is potentially their last season, I was expecting Team Rocket to have a bit more of a punch instead of dancing the same dance they've done for 20 years. They were as easy to defeat as when the show was running on a never-ending format.
Since it's a nostalgia trip, I'm surprised this was a new Latias, but I'm not against it. Hopefully she has another appearance down the line like the end of the episode suggests.
As for the animation, it was fine, passable enough, nothing special.
If I had to rate it, it'd be like a 6 or something.

I unironically don't think we'll ever see leagues anymore in thenew Pokemon anime with Riko...in the Rikonime.
The Gen1-6 leagues set too high a standard. yeah, SM and JN had nonsense trash leagues but that's just expected from the nu-ashnime. If there's one thing the ashnime always got right it's the sense of competition in this stuff - Ash isn't the "special" protagonist, each one of his opponents is just as much a protagonist of their own story, Ritchie even had a Pikachu, Paul had a similar ambition, Alain also met legendaries, etc.
So victory in the league is not decided by protagonist power but rather by actual battle tactics/luck/training/strategies which made it all good.
I really don't think the Riko arc will span another 1000+ episodes to really invest in the whole tournament setups, it wouldn't look good in the modern format anyways.
It'll probably focus more on Villain Team arcs, personal drama or whatever.

posts.com: So how does Pokerus work in this? I know it can only effect eggs and only ones that you manually put in the daycare, but beyond that I am not sure what to do and if I can fuck it up somehow if I don't watch out what I am doing and lock out a large amount of my team from getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
You can't mess it up in any way. Pokerus spreads between eggs in the daycare that share a typing. Newly infected eggs cannot immediately spread it until they've hatched. "Contagious" and "Resistant" are misnomers: Contagious just means it has pokerus with less than 50 EVs accumulated while Resistant means you passed that point and will see diminishing returns on EV gain. Both spread it the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly Crystal specifically does have some issues.
Crystal removes mons like Mareep and GIrafarig and moved Magmar to Kanto. This makes teambuilding more annoying. I find that mid-Johto the available pokemon lack in fire power. I think the distribution is too dependent on the Odd Egg too, having to reset and hatch the egg constantly to get a decent Fire or Electric type sucks. But you do still have the Elemental punches available, so if you ever get tired you can just load them up on a Kadabra or Typhlosion and just fuck the game up.
Otherwise I think Johto games are fine. Grinding isn't hard, you can use the good and super rods to fish up pokemon that give decent exp, surfing gives good exp too. Trainers in the Johto portion of the game aren't very high leveled anyway so you don't need to grind much. Whitney and Morty are the hardest bosses in Johto and they can be dealt with. HGSS's rematch system is also pretty good for exp, it sucks that it's limited based on what day it is but you can call trainers for rematches quickly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52960373
Solid remake, but it’s ultimately worse than GSC. The only major flaws with Crystal are tied to the mon distribution (can be fixed when emulating) and the lack of easy grinding methods for Stadium 2 (irrelevant for most people).

HGSS lacks the charm of the original OST, sprites, and overall art direction, even if there are a few standouts in the new OST. It’s also tied to the painfully slow Gen 4 engine, removing the snappy gameplay of Gen 2. HGSS fucks the level curve beyond repair by removing badge boosts and implementing the split (without making any attempt at rebalancing old mon). Following mon were very cool, though, and the battle frontier was appreciated. HGSS does have a few solid QoL improvements; I just don’t think it’s enough to replace GSC.

>Seth McMahill, Assistant Manager of Product Marketing at Nintendo, has been working exclusively on Pokémon games throughout his career at the company.
>When we spoke with McMahill recently, we asked if he had any interesting or amusing stories to tell from his days localizing the older games. McMahill recalled a couple of instances for us.
>“When you’re naming them, you’re together in a room with a counterpart from NCL (Nintendo Co. Ltd.),” McMahill shared. “We would basically have a thesaurus, a whiteboard on the wall, and would lock ourselves in for days on end, and the days would turn into months.”
>He continued: “The craziest one is… my wife was about to have a baby. So I’m at home, going through baby name books. I’m at work, going through baby name books, along with thesauruses and dictionaries. And after a while, stuff starts to sound weird. So, we had Piplup (Japanese name: Pochama), and the description from Japan was: ‘the sound of a small pebble in the water’. That was what we had to come up with.”
>McMahill recalls: “What we came up with was Piploop, which sounded like ‘poop’.”
>“And we didn’t even think of that,” he says. “No one thought of it. And we were talking to another group, saying we’d finally figured it out, and they went: ‘Poop?’ They said it sounded like poop. And I said, ‘It does not sound like poop! You don’t know what you’re talking about; I’ve been doing this for years!'”
>“And then, finally, after a good night’s rest, I thought: ‘That does sound like poop…’ So, we ended up with Piplup, which was the final name.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52976348
>They don't punish the opponent, they protect you.
Yeah, too much. It makes switching with such bulky Pokemon too easy and makes pivoting too oppressive. If you actually played the Gen 8 Meta, you'd know how oppressive Teleport+Future Sight was, and that was enabled with the help of HDB. Even without that, slow turning into an extremely threatening Pokemon held back by its frailty is oppressive. It's why you saw a bunch of Slowbro+Weavile pairings, aside from the previously mentioned FuturePort tech, but you still also say Blissey+Weavile, Fini+Weavile, and DragaZera+Weavile, and then also saw tons of Melmetal as that shit was the only thing that could reliably beat Pivot+Weavile.
And also keep in mind, tons of things lost Knock Off in Gen 9 due to transfers replacing your moveset with level up moves. So if Gholdengo were to be banned, HDBs would make any attempts to hazard stack pointless in a game where without Gholdengo it's really hard to keep hazards up.
>Gho actively punishes you for merely existing.
How exactly does Gholdengo do this? And even if your exaggerated claims were true, Gholdengo's presence is still definitely a positive one because it's the only respite against the anti-hazards creep. It's much more welcoming than pivots being completely immune to their main form of counterplay and biggest limiter.
>A defensive item is never oppressive by definition.
Not only is this just straight up false, as defensive teams can absolutely be oppressive, but it also implies that only defensive teams or even defensive Pokemon use HDBs.Again, if you actually played the game, you'd know that NEARLY EVERYTHING uses fucking HDBs. Obviously lots of slow walls used this item, as well as Stealth Rock weak Pokemon, but anything that was going to switch around often used it. Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Zeraora, ect. It was so common that between all the Pokemon that use HDBs, Leftovers only beats it by 1 Pokemon, and this also includes CAPmons and NatDex meta too.

actually, let's go through the other types so we can see what they represent. sans Psychic and Fairy because those have already been done.

>Normal: everything that isn't the other types
>Fighting: physical strength, specific fighting styles, or justice
>Flying: wind and things that fly
>Bug: vague category of invertabrate nuisances, but mostly insects
>Grass: plants(and fungi), nature
>Fire: fire, hot things
>Water: water and things that live in or near water
>Rock: rocks, also sandstorm for some reason
>Ground: sand, mud, and the things that live there
>Ice: cold things
>Electric: electricity, being fast?
>Ghost: spirits, possessed objects, whatever Decidueye is
>Poison: venom and toxic substances
>Dragon: dragons, could also be raw power depending on your interpretation
>Dark: malice and deceit
>Steel: metal, machines
all simple and easy to understand. psychic and fairy are the outliers, and between them fairy is far worse

Okay I'm to rant about something that's probably super autistic. I was planning to make an entire thread about this, but I'll sperg about here since it's relevant:

The fact that types actually exist in canon absolutely confounds me. The fact that types actually exist in-universe, and aren't just a gameplay mechanic, makes no goddamn sense.
THIS is why the thematic vagueness of Fairy bothers me. What the fuck is a fairy? What is fairy-typing? What does it mean to be a fairy type? What are the criteria for a Pokemon to be classified as such? I could maybe accept your "magical girly fairy bullshit" explanation if types were just a gameplay mechanic and thus only need a meta-explanation rather than a canonical one, but I can't accept it as a canonical justification. What, does being feminine make something a fairy type? If so, then why is Grimmsnarl a fairy type but Lopunny isn't? Or hell, why aren't all female Pokemon fairy types? Are fairy types spirits? Then why is Magearna a fairy type while Ninetales isn't? Are you telling a robot is a spirit, but a kitsune isn't? Or fuck, why is Alolan Ninetales a fairy type, but regular Ninetales isn't? Good worldbuilding demands internally consistent rules and logic, and that can't be found in the Fairy type, or even types as whole for that matter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52979633
And no, Fairy is not the only type that's guilty of this. Others ITT have already ranted about Psychic types so I won't indulge about them too much here, although I do feel like pointing out that Magic and Psychic powers are thematically quite closely related, more than I think most people realize. The actual definition of magic is creating change through will, which is similar to what Psychic powers are as well. In fact, Pokemon wouldn't even be the first setting to consider magic and psychic powers to be related, just look at WH40K.

A type guilty of thematic inconsistency that I feel doesn't get mentioned enough is Normal type. At first glance, it seems that >>52979523 is right about normal type. It's what a Pokemon that doesn't possess a typing is. But the problem is, there a ton of dual-type normal types. Why are these Pokemon normal type? What makes a Drampa Normal/Dragon instead of just Dragon? Why is Pyroar Fire/Normal instead of just Fire? This clearly shows that Normal isn't just the "has no type" type, it's something else. But what is it, then? What does being Normal type mean?

And what about Fighting? All Pokemon fight, so what separates fighting types from everything else? Does it refer to Pokemon that are highly skilled, experienced, or physically powerful? Then why is a level 1 Machop a fighting type while a level 100 Hydreigon isn't?

By the way, I'm just one problem regarding the canonicity of types in the lore here. I focused on thematic inconsistency because that's what this thread is about, but there are other problems I have with them as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think the people that call pre-split unplayable or hard to go back to haven't tried.
In the earlier gens, there was actually a strong bias towards physical types having underwhelming type matchups or movepools, while special types got to have a lot of the stronger moves. Bug, Poison, Ghost, Fighting, Flying, and to a lesser extent Rock were all pretty bad attacking types in gen 1, and they weren't buffed much in gen 2 save for ghost. Ground was the only physical type with good attacks and good matchups, but it also had a rather common type that was immune to it.
What this effectively did was make attack your "normal-type attack" stat while special was your "elemental attack" stat. This also made physical and special attackers more inherently unique from one-another, just because the type chart would have more or lesser influence over your move choices.

But I do think it was a good change for the series, a good amount of pokemon concepts just didn't function pre-split and I think it's better for diversity between pokemon to be determined by abilities, movepools, or type-specific mechanics like weather.

>>52983398
Forgot to point out another thing from earlier gens, the distribution of moves that raise/lower stats.
In gen 1, one of the only moves that raised or lowered special was Amnesia, and that move was only learned by Mewtwo (postgame legendary), Poliwrath (basically the only good thing about it back then), Snorlax (physical attacker), and Slowbro (only available by using the super rod in obscure locations, or traversing an optional dungeon in the middle of an ocean)
The other move was growth, which was exclusive to grass, a type with little else going for it back then.
In gen 3, they added calm mind, which was available as a single-use TM (earned from Tate and Liza, or Sabrina in frlg) and rarely learned by level up.
Nasty Plot wasn't added until gen 4.
Getting to raise your special attack by two stages in 1 turn was originally a rare mechanic for rare pokemon, then they immediately nerfed that move and offered no replacement until physical and special were less inherently different.
Additionally, moves that lower special stats of the opponent are rare to this day, with most of them being RNG reliant, unless it's confide.
So while special attackers had all of the cool elemental types, physical attackers had swords dance.

>>52984068
I do wonder how you feel about Alakazam, because it similarly outspeeds a lot of mons in Gen 1, and a Psychic off of 135 Sp. Atk is similarly potent, and only other Psychic types properly resisted it back then.

That said, I think you're really mis-diagnosing the cause there. Darmanitan having 140 base attack is what lets it blast through everything. It might be somewhat weaker if it had to rely on non-Fire moves, but do you really think Gamefreak would still be designing pokemon the same way if they hadn't implemented the split? Would they have given Darmanitan 140 attack if Fire was still special, or would they have pushed the powercreep in a different direction to give it sky-high special attack?
If it was still physical, do you think it would truly be as gimped as it might be in the old games? When it gets a wide variety of powerful coverage moves that mons would have killed for in Gen 1? Moves like Hammer Arm and Superpower beat Submission hands-down.

This isn't all stemming from the fact that Darmanitan can use Fire Punch with its massive attack stat. It's stemming from the fact that Stats across the board have gotten higher and more min-maxed, movepools have gotten broader, and moves themselves have gotten more powerful with fewer drawbacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52984564
>I see no evidence to make me believe the split has any effect on the design of Pokemon stats
Yes, exactly. Gamefreak would be engaging in power creep, split or no split. It's difficult to say in a vacuum whether the Darmanitan we got would be the exact same in terms of stats/movepool if the split had never been implemented.

>You can even look at Rhydon and see how even with high attack physical stab it wasn't broken because everything else was balanced
Rhydon lacks quite a lot in terms of speed, and having a 4x weakness to both Grass and Ground doesn't help it. That alone makes it less practical for an in-game playthrough, compounded by the fact that unlike Darumaka which can be found just after the third gym, Rhyhorn would normally be found after the 4th unless you deliberately skip Erika, and also has to wait until level 42 to evolve, rather than 35.
If you're not talking about in-game, then Rhydon was notable in competitive for both RBY and GSC, but part of that is just due to how few good Ground types there were otherwise. Once you get to RSE, you see Swampert taking over that role, and that's still pre-split.

I think in terms of an even playing field, I do see something.
With Stab being more of a given due to the split, that means some of the differences between mons have been reduced, but in some ways that does exacerbate the other factors, such as stats. If there were two mons where one had better stats but a worse movepool, then evening the difference in movepool puts all the focus on the stats, which makes things less even.
However, that's not exclusive to the split. Heracross was noteworthy in Gen 3 thanks to Megahorn and some solid Fighting moves, but when it came to Gen 4 Scizor became the more notable Bug type thanks to not having to rely on Hidden Power, Metal Claw, or Silver Wind. Bug and Steel were both physical types, so nothing changed, but getting new moves is what allowed it to excel.

posts.com:
>>52982254
Dragon was Special before gen 4 so if that was still the case a Tyrantrum wouldn't be able to use Scale Shot, Dragon Claw, or Outrage against other Dragon-type Pokémon effectively off of its 69 Special Attack. Other than that the elemental fang moves (Fire, Ice and Electric were Special), Crunch (Dark was Special), Psychic Fangs (Psychic was Special), Play Rough (assuming if Fairy would be Special) would also be useless.

So basically its only physical options would be:

- Stone Edge / Head Smash / Meteor Beam (would have been physical back then)
- Close Combat
- Earthquake
- Iron Head / Iron Tail

And then you have Pokémon like Sharpedo and Feraligatr not even being able to make effective use of their STABS since they were physical attackers whose STABS at the time only consisted of Special moves. Not to mention every special attacking Pokémon of predominantly-physical types like Aurorus would be fucked since Meteor Beam and Ancient "Power" would be physical.

Unfortunately it did screw over Pokémon like Sceptile (even though that can be fixed by swapping its attacking stats).

posts.com:
Posting a quick guide before I do a proper good one for hunting on area zero then for anyone interested

First we decide on the pokemon.
Once we get that set, we follow this
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1Krmy76O7u4ZHG-QySfmNa-85UHwDnvJIldfOhr-cxRs/htmlview#

We save before we union circle.
We do the circle and fly to the area zero gate.
Depending on what we hunt, we either do one sandwich at once for everyone, one sandwich for two, one for each, etc

We split, the more ground we cover more spawns we get = higher odds of shinies, we've gotten up to 5 in a single 30 min sandwich run.

Here's the basics:

>1) Know where it can spawn, go to that area, during union circle only 5 pokemon can spawn near you.
>2) Move around, move back and forth, move between two locations, etc, you just need to keep spawning them while also checking each one of them

>3) If you find a shiny, CARE, DO NOT ENGAGE IT, SAVE AND AVOID FIGHTING IT

>4) Announce what you found and where in the thread, wait for confirmation on whos catching it, when to restart, etc

>But why wouldn't I just catch it?

On union circle the player that finds the shiny, aka, the cartridge that generates it, can save in front and once they restart the shiny will be there since it originated for them.
This means that up to two players can catch the same shiny, the player that finds it after he restarts and one other person.

Example: I find a shiny Scream Tail, I can save in front, say in thread "shiny scream tail in front of lab 4, already saved and you're free to engage" so you can just find it and catch it, after that we ideally keep running the rest of the sandwich and if nothing shows up, I restart


Couple things to know;
>If it aggros DON'T RUN, union circle mons despawn if you run away
>You're likely to get other shiny mons on the way, so for these and the paradox bring a pokemon that can make catching them easier like a Breloom or Gallade.

Anyone else can join for the record, 4 max.

>>52986103
To my knowledge, the only legitimate source of Beast Balls is for completing the Pokédex, and a small chance for winning the Academy Ace tournament.
Auction house only has the Apricorn Balls + Dream Ball.

Like I mentioned, I've stayed on v1.0.1 to facilitate the item duping glitch. It's a little time consuming, but my Violet save now has a stack of 999 Beast Balls, and I've got some 50+ on my Scarlet save.
Violet is my primary game which I'm going to update to v1.1 this weekend so I can do the Cinderace tera raid.
I'm currently stockpiling hard to get items before I do the update. I want lots of ability patches, Apricorn Balls, Master Balls, Bottle Caps, etc.

Cloning one ability patch can be sold for 125,000. That lets you buy 6 Bottle Caps, 12 Vitamins, etc, so it's faster than cloning those items individually.
Cash caps at 9,999,999 though.

how much of a difference is a 3 star mon to a perfect stats mon. same goes for shadow mods. it seems all my shadow mons have garbage stats

i keep getting conflicting answers on reddit and forums

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52975532
>how much of a difference is a 3 star mon to a perfect stats mon
Usually very little difference, however it will be noticeable in Master League, especially if you haven't maxed it out (plus I guess for lvl. 50 Pokémon in any other leagues that require perfect IVs to be most viable). Higher attack breaks charge move ties, and you'll never know when that extra defense point or HP comes in clutch.

>same goes for shadow mods. it seems all my shadow mons have garbage stats
Also not that important for those. Especially when it comes to normal Pokémon vs. shadow Pokémon for raids, zero IV shadow Pokémon are virtually always better than 100% IV normal Pokémon.

The only difference that I've found particularly noteworthy when comparing performance of shadow Pokémon is that a typical 1* Shadow Salamence with the Community Day move Outrage is usually slightly worse than your average 3* Shadow Dragonite, that can learn Outrage whenever, in raids. I assume a similar thing can be said about a 1* Shadow Machamp and a 3* Shadow Hariyama, but all four of those Pokémon are good in raids regardless of IVs.

Some studios become so used to drawing certain things that they don't even realize they're veering away from the ref sheet. >>52966227
I don't think it ever filters your posts. You can say whatever you like and it won't be deleted.

Instead it deletes the bot's responses. This might mean that you see a response being "typed" which suddenly vanishes and is replaced with another one. If that response is also deemed too lewd it will also be deleted. You'll get a chat error and just won't receive a response at all.

So if you write:

"*I put my penis in her vagina*"

and the bot tries to write

"I love the feeling your your penis in my vagina!"

That reply is going straight in the bin.

Unfortunately the bot is cleverer than just censoring sex words - it tries to pick up on context and will delete replies with moans, descriptions of pleasure, and even consent for sexual acts, even if there's nothing explicit in the content of the post itself.

One of the stupid things is that it doesn't censor crying, refusal of consent, begging you to stop, etc. so rape stuff gets through a lot easier.

>>52973394
I started in 2017 in my challenge to 100% every generation with unique challenges (so no nat dex, but yes regional dex + Stadium games + Battle Facilities + contests + etc) with no assistance from outside hardware for the sake of injecting or cheating in Pokemon, but events were still very much on the table.
Once you hit gen 3, you just have this massive wall of things to do that if you are not a NEET will take you years to complete. It took me 3 1/2 years to learn and beat the Battle Frontier in Emerald. I then raised a different unique team for all Colosseums in Pokemon Colosseum. I have yet to do all of the eReader cards in Ruby.
The hard part about trying to enjoy the past games is that just like all Pokemon games, they are carried by how good the multiplayer aspects of the games are. If you are playing alone, of course you are going to get burnt out after a gym or two. You've played something very similar before and know all of the mechanics. It's not like the series has changed that much since gen 4. Playing gens 4+ is a lot better if you find people online to play with. There's pkmnclassic.net, here (although people here actually do not play the games), other sites like Orange Islands in Smogon, and of course people you know irl to play with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just beat Red in crystal and it was a fucking BATTLE.
I was grinding up my team of Feraligatr, Gengar, Slowking, Umbreon and Snorlax and was going to use an onix I got from Mt. Silver for his Pikachu.
I lost Snorlax while grinding the elite four at level 59! Disaster!
So I got pissed and decided to use my rare candies and just fight Red. Fuck it. Just fuck it.
Final team was:
Bepis the Feraligatr lv 62
Mr. Knox the Slowking lv 62
Tsushima the Gengar lv 64
Enoch the Umbreon lv 62
Gibraltar the Onix lv 48
a random electrode from rocket hideout that I sacked to Charizard during the fight.

Onix trolled pikachu to death in like 30 turns lol
I let it die to Espeon then Umbreon obviously came in and walled for days
He sends in Snorlax. I try to toxic/confuse ray troll it for a bit and he uses rest, it didn't work out so I went into Gengar.
Mean look then curse, two moves I'd had to keep on him since the very beginning and it finally paid off and I killed the fatass.
Red sends Venusaur to be 2HKO'd by my Gengar's psychic.
Then Charizard comes out.....with sun up already.
I sack Electrode, go into Feraligatr and unfortunately lose him to a crit flamethrower +fire spin chip, but gengar is able to come in and pick him off with thunder punch.
Finally, blastoise. I go for curse yet again (I had leftovers equipped so I got back to full on snorlax), and then go into Slowking to sit on him for a couple more turns.

Only Slowking and Gengar survived the end, but it was an epic battle.

On to the next. I'm thinking possibly Red/Fire Red or....something else. Give suggestions please! This was a really fun nuzlocke aside from a lot of grinding. Gengar was the MVP the whole run pretty much. 40 hours of playtime!

posts.com:
Franchise run with species clause so far
Despite almost losing my Crystal run, I thought GSC was pretty alright. If you have checks for Bugsy's Scyther, Whitney's Miltank and Morty's Gengar, most of the midgame will be on the easier side even with hardcore rules since Jasmine's lv 35 Steelix will let you overlevel and crush everything until Lance
Lance also having a lv 50 Dragonite means you might be over ten levels higher than most of the rest of the E4, so you really only have to prep for him

Overall, lots of fun so far, but I'm glad I'm getting into the games with more fun movesets to be used. I just hope I didn't use too many Kanto mons since I need those for FRLG and Let's Go

>>52970691
grass types are sadly very shit in Johto. There are some random trainer battles where of course it'll be useful to have a grass type, but all of the main battles shit all over grass types. Every single one. There are no favorable matchups, only semi-okay matchups. The one exception I can think of it Chuck's Poliwrath being water type. But electric does it better + is useful vs more fights.
Hoppip is not bad though, he has speed and great utility moves and can absolutely troll anything in the game to death with sleep powder and leech seed. Great team support if you have a setup pokemon with a boosting move or something that would benefit from being in against a sleeping opponent (pretty much anything).
He is a chore to train, but I find him fun to use.
Just know if you use a grass type, its an uphill battle.

This thread is for Hacks and/or Clones. Come in and get free stuff!

>Is this thread legit or not?

>No one has fulfilled my request yet? Why?
Injectors fulfill requests out of the goodness of their own hearts, and on their own time. Be patient.

>How can I help the process go faster?
Use PKHex to create .PK9 files to help Injectors quickly load in the pokemon you want. Follow the guide.
PKHeX Guide by IZIX:

>What's the difference between this thread and Wi-Fi General?
Wi-Fi General does not condone hacks, and asking for or offering a hack over there will result in a completely unnecessary shitstorm. Play the game however you want, but if you want injections/genned Pokémon, play here in a more friendly, less autistic environment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52983451
PID's get flagged because the game can tell on some level that the mon was created and not natural in the game. For example giving your PID to Koraidon and then injecting it as soon as you start the game, the game knows Koriadon can only be caught in area zero, but your trainer has not been there so there's no logical way for Koriadon to have your PID when caught if you didnt even unlock the area yet. It could also be a way of preventing copying someone's Pokemon so that 2 PID's exist for 1 trainer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52978982
restoration of fossils utilizes a technic which requires the use of a synthesized genes to fill in the gaps like Jurassic Park does. These genes were originally created from rock type pokemon, due to rock types having biological make up of living rocks/minerals. This however changes many fossil pokemon, making them hybrids, and in some cases cannot ever be fully restored. Aerodactyl being an oddity, as through mega evolution, it's genes are restored to its prime, which retains its rock type, so more research must be done if this is the true Aerodactyl, or if the modified genes are added onto the restored genes or not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52978982
The fossil restoration is more or less used the same method as the guys who runs Jurrasic Park/World; they retrieve the DNA from fossils and use the DNA of extant specimens to fill in the blanks. It's why Mr. Fuji's cloning attempt only created an unstoppable monster and Cara Lass's resurrection machine creates mishmashed abombinations that were somehow alive.

>Would Cynthia hang out with Lance?
They go on dragon-related adventures together, Cynthia not quite being a dedicated dragon master but being accepted as one by the elders from her mastery of the likes of Garchomp and Kommo-o. They explore rugged wilderness, train by battling dangerous monsters, and occasionally busting up bad guys and saving the world/universe.

>Would Cynthia hang out with Steven
They go exploring ancient ruins in the middle of the desert or the jungle or something, like Laura Croft teaming up with Indiana Jones, except Steven keeps getting distracted by random cool rocks he finds lying around. Cynthia finds his nerding-out over geology amusing and he finds her nerding-out over anthropology inbteresting.

>Or does she prefer girls?
Diantha is too busy with glamour and Cynthia finds her boring. Iris is a minor and Cynthia isn't legally allowed to be within 100 feet of her. Geeta is a scrub and Cynthia has to resist the urge to dethrone her.

>>52964491
>>52971825
There's a (yeah, I know) fanfic I'm reading that I like which is essentially the best background characterization of Cyrus I've ever personally read, and Cynthia is *very* flawed in it, but to a degree where she's honestly almost unrecognizable from most portrayals of her (uses violence and strength as her first resort, uninterested in mythology, arrogant, reckless). Basically if Cynthia acted like more like a typical champion than the well rounded individual she is, because the author wanted to portray her as someone who is too self centered and acts according to her own interests without realizing the consequences on others until it's too late, and so has a lot of character growth as a result. I like it, but I definitely can't reconcile that portrayal with the usual nurturing, wise, and scholarly incarnation that we all know and love

https://archiveofourown.org/works/27834952?view_full_work=true

>>52984043
It's true. Making this widely distributed is what led to the long, slow sanitization and dilution of fighting type themes and concepts. These generic "bursts of power" moves did not evoke specific martial arts, and generations later, the fighting pokemon themselves lost actual nuances when it came to design. Now the type is slapped on anything with a weak pun or connection to the type.

Fighting type was a distinct type from all others because they resembled actual martial arts and techniques. Now it's anything that "fights well". It has become the biggest criticism fans have about the existence of its type.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52983102
"Not fun" and frustrating are different things though, and cc is inherently frustrating. What's "not fun" is when things become unfair, such as a stealthed hit, followed by confuse ray, followed by a shadow sneak stealthed hit. It's like 5 seconds of cc if you don't just immediately die. I think fixes are pretty simple.

2 things, 1 is a global nerf to stealth. It should be punishable rather than a free escape. There are a few ways to do this, either you become visible when you're close enough to the stealthed character, or if you're within its radius, after a set amount of time you can see it, and lots of other potential ways. Aside from that, hitting a stealthed character should reveal it.

And internal cooldowns on his 'fear' cc. Can't activate again within 8 seconds. It won't end up being anti-fun that way and not make it such a brain dead character. Also probably nerf the damage of that stealthed hit a bit. 2 of those and a confuse ray shouldn't be taking a Defender to less than half life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52982222
Most MOBAs let you purchase stealth detection, either around you or as map vision items you can throw down that the little stealth rat has to play around.
There's usually other balancing factors, like the stealth chara being relatively weak early and/or dying immediately if caught, being revealed from stealth if they take AoE damage/not being able to easily re-stealth while in combat, having lower utility instead of like 4-5 seconds of disable, etc.

Also other MOBAs have way less focus on stealing each other's farm so it's less obnoxious and more of a "why did you bother" if the stealth chara pops out at your goal/tower to steal a single NPC and fuck off. In fact, in most other MOBAs "goals" generally have stealth detection and a fairly strong attack until late game, so a stealth character is likely to lose half their health if they come fuck with you at your goal, instead of being incentivized to constantly fuck around there trying to stack.

Partially want to expand on this by instead aiming it more at trade evolutions such as Magmortar, Electivire, and Rhyperior. They gain more power by evolving into bigger, more heavy hitting pokemon, but at the cost of living on average much shorter than their counterparts.
>Electabuzz on average live 40 years, but Electivire usually live up to 32. This is often attributed to muscle spasms alongside what are often known as “Power Surges” where a Pokemon, usually of older age, uses an electric attack only to suffer some kind of shock similar to a stroke. These cases may range from the need for organ transplant to even instantaneous death. While the more agile Electabuzz can withstand itself, aging Electivire often hide from conflict in order to prevent such dangers.
>Magmar usually live 30 years, while even a healthy Magmortar can live up to being 25 tops. Their front talons easily get infected due to the flaps, and while their bulky, round physique can take many hits, they become prone to many respiratory illnesses. Many Magmortar autopsies reveal that their lungs often get cooked from the inside attributed to their body attempting to expel more fire than it can handle.

Are you shitheads retarded?

The people telling you to fuck off are saying
>there's bigger issues to cry about than whether they found a way to squeeze a thousand pokemon into the game or not.

Look at scarlet and violet. Look at all its problems and the few things it did right.
There's so much to unpack here.
>"I don't get to transfer my miltank from Home over"
is not worth unpacking.

I'd love a region spanning game with a full pokedex where every area of the game has a massive number of pokemon to catch... but I actually think I'm in the minority. Especially when you think about what that means for a gameplay perspective.
While the idea is nice, how many of pokemon's actual playerbase would come anywhere NEAR completing such a pokedex?
You'd be looking more like the Witcher 3 with only a third of players reaching the first town before they got overwhelmed and quit.
- and don't go shouting about "Zoomer attention spans" when you're playing and bitching about a game for children.

But even after all that, I'm still not defending cut content.
Including them in the game isn't the same as allowing the pokedex to store the data for them so players can transfer or trade them.
But it's not not a high priority.
When they're cutting corners to release a game, which they clearly did for SV, the last thing I want them to be wasting time on is including the other half of all pokemon that aren't even encounterable, just to please the autists.

I feel like sinnoh get's a lot of hate these days.
We're coming off of the peak of the gen 4 nostalgia era when people who played DPP as kids became old enough to post here, so there's a sense of animosity, and that's understandable. Not to mention BDSP sucking ass.
But, personally? I really like sinnoh, mainly platinum, but I think even diamond and pearl had their place.
I don't think enough is said about how gen 4 is ultimately trying to be the spiritual successor to gen 2. Gen 2 really tried to be more than just an RPG campaign, it tried to create a world that promoted a gradual sense of progression while you spent your downtime doing the time based events and really getting comfortable and immersed in the world. Gen 3 largely removed this entire focus, and while I think it's good in an all new way, it undoubtedly did lose an inherent appeal that gen 2 had. Gen 4, by contrast, literally brought back all the major time based events from gen 2, adding them on top of the gen 3 stuff. The time system is back, but more than that, it also affects encounters, and you also have stuff like honey trees, the safari zone with it's changing encounter tables, etc. These sorts of features may be controversial but they play into a similar thing that the rarer gen 2 mons do. The reason they're so rare is because the player is expected to remain in the world for a long time, constantly interacting with it's more repetitious features like daily events. Simple stuff like slathering honey on a tree and then checking back 6 hours later, or waiting to get called about a swarm, is meant to be background stuff that adds to the gameplay loop. This, mixed with the jazzy laid back vibe of the Sinnoh region, creates a game that feels ridiculously relaxing to play. It's a long, and admittedly slow adventure, but that's just the sort of experience it's trying to be. Gen 4 takes the best parts of gen 2 and 3 and combines them into what is, for me, the ultimate pokemon experience.
